H0.text: Feldspar and quartz are the two most common silicates.

H1.text: Olivine and quartz are the two most common silicates.

H2.text: Micas and feldspar are the two most common silicates.

H3.text: Micas and quartz are the two most common silicates.

A4.text: Feldspar is a major component of the Earth's crust and is extensively discussed in the text, indicating its high abundance.

A5.text: Quartz is widely found in igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks, as noted in geological contexts, supporting its status as a common silicate.

A6.text: Olivine is not prominently mentioned in the text, suggesting it is not as common as feldspar and quartz.

A7.text: Micas are discussed but are not as prevalent as feldspar and quartz in the Earth's crust, attacking the hypothesis that they are the most common.

A8.text: Micas are not as abundant as quartz, attacking the hypothesis that they are the two most common silicates.
